args: Is this article primarily about a new action or announcement by the Trump administration/White House/Executive? Respond simply with "yes" or "no" . Judge forces lawyers for fired inspectors general to withdraw TRO request Lawyers for eight inspectors general suing the Trump administration over their firings last month were forced by an angry federal judge to withdraw their motion seeking a temporary restraining order. Judge Ana C. Reyes of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia tore into the attorneys for the plaintiffs in a brief but heated hearing on Friday afternoon. Reyes demanded to know why the plaintiffs’ attorneys waited 21 days after the firings to file their lawsuit, only to then seek emergency same-day relief. She ticked off the list of emergency actions that have flooded the federal dockets and then limited the attorneys to “yes” and “no” answers. She also objected to the plaintiffs’ counsel comparing the facts of their case to those of Hampton Dellinger, the fired head of the Office of Special Counsel who sued the Trump administration last week. Dellinger argued in his complaint that his termination violated a law that shields the leaders of independent agencies from removal by the president. The inspectors general, however, are arguing that their firing was illegal because Trump did not give Congress 30 days’ notice of his decision as required by law. After forcing the plaintiffs to withdraw their motion for a temporary restraining order, the parties agreed to an expedited schedule. The government must reply to the lawsuit by Feb. 21. “Why on earth this could not have been decided in a five-minute phone call is beyond me,” Reyes said. She said she considered sanctioning the plaintiff’s attorneys but had more pressing matters on her docket.
